Speaker: Scorpion
Dialogue: Machine's broken again.

Speaker: Frog
Dialogue: Oh no, missing your fourth cup of the day? You could say that borders on…. criminal.

Speaker: Scorpion
Dialogue: Fourth, and a fifth if you keep that up.

Speaker: Phone
Dialogue: *ring ring, ring ring*

Speaker: Margot
Dialogue: You're needed. Now. There's been a murder. *click*

Speaker: Frog
Dialogue: Pleasure as always, Margot.

Speaker: Scorpion
Dialogue: Something's not right here.

Speaker: Frog
Dialogue: Hey, Ernie? You might want to see this.

Speaker: Frog
Dialogue: Ernie?

Speaker: Scorpion
Dialogue: What is it?

Speaker: Frog
Dialogue: You seemed a little out of it there. Is everything okay?

Speaker: Scorpion
Dialogue: It's just…. This scene? It reminds me of the day my parents died. They told me they never found the bodies… just bits. A struggle maybe, and they were gone. But they never found more than a limb or two, just like this guy.

Speaker: Frog
Dialogue: Want me to cover for you while you take a breather?

Speaker: Scorpion
Dialogue: Don't worry about me. Worry about this guy…. Or what's left of him.

Speaker: Frog
Dialogue: We got a name on him?

Speaker: Scorpion
Dialogue: Daedalus, last name Doornail. He dropped his wallet, but he wasn't holding much. Poor sod was on his way home, I'd assume.

Speaker: Frog
Dialogue: Well, there must be something that'll give us a "leg" up in this investigation. Let's look around, eh?

Speaker: Frog
Dialogue: Sorry.

Speaker: Frog
Dialogue: I think we must have picked this place clean twice over, but I'm not seeing… well, anything.

Speaker: Scorpion
Dialogue: Are you thinking what I am?

Speaker: Frog
Dialogue: Yep. Our perp's done a runner. He kills, makes a break for it… and then what?

Speaker: Scorpion
Dialogue: Well, where did he go? I'm willing to bet that a guy who leaves evidence lying around like this ain't exactly careful about where he stashes the evidence. Let's look around and see what we can dig up.

Speaker: Scorpion
Dialogue: Ferd? Take a look at this place.

Speaker: Frog
Dialogue: Cute! Wonder if they do pizza.

Speaker: Scorpion
Dialogue: Really?

Speaker: Frog
Dialogue: We didn't have dinner, you know. What's that sign say?

Speaker: Scorpion
Dialogue: I think that's all the clues our killer left us, at least here. Little careless, isn't he?

Speaker: Frog
Dialogue: Very.

Speaker: Scorpion
Dialogue: We ought to see if anyone saw anything. Shall we?

Speaker: Frog
Dialogue: After you, Ernie.

Speaker: Scorpion
Dialogue: Well, we're back where we started. The best vantage point as far as eyewitnesses go has got to be somewhere around here.

Speaker: Frog
Dialogue: I'll tackle the cafe.

Speaker: Scorpion
Dialogue: Then I'll stay out here and keep watch. You never know, they come back to the scene sometimes - for what reason, I'll never know. This one clearly isn't too worried about hiding his tracks.

Speaker: Lin
Dialogue: Hey, Ferd! Fancy seeing you here again. Back for another?

Speaker: Frog
Dialogue: Not this time, my friend. Here on a case. Got a second?

Speaker: Lin
Dialogue: Always got a minute for my best bud! This is Ida.

Speaker: Ida
Dialogue: Blblblbl. (Nice to meet you.)

Speaker: Frog
Dialogue: Don't suppose you saw anything last night, my friend? There was a murder, not far from here. We're taking statements.

Speaker: Lin
Dialogue: Oh golly, that's awful! No, last night I was a little out of sorts. Drowning my sorrows, I guess you could say. *He glances meaningfully at Ida* Weather was awful, so you couldn't see much out those windows.

Speaker: Ida
Dialogue: Blblblb, blblblblbl. Blb.

Speaker: Frog
Dialogue: Good for him. He's had a rocky love life, that one.

Speaker: Scorpion
Dialogue: It's quiet tonight. Nice.

Speaker: Scorpion
Dialogue: It gets so busy in the morning, when the city wakes up for work. And again at night when they return. I much prefer these twilight hours, when it's a little less noisy… helps me clear my head.

Speaker: Scorpion
Dialogue: It was really coming down last night, huh? I doubt anyone made it home without wet socks.

Speaker: Frog
Dialogue: Who's that hiding in the shadows? I don't like how she's looking at me. It's… unsettling. Does she know something?

Speaker: Laurie
Dialogue: Red, red like blood. So much blood there was, and so much more to come if he gets his way.

Speaker: Frog
Dialogue: Er, what was that?

Speaker: Laurie
Dialogue: Rude fellow he was, never once apologized for bumping into poor Laurie. Seemed to think himself quite the important gentleman, fancy new outfit and all.

Speaker: Frog
Dialogue: What could that possibly mean? I don't think I'll get much out of her. She gives me the creeps.

Speaker: Finley
Dialogue: Hey, barkeep. Another.

Speaker: Frog
Dialogue: Ferdinand J. Croaker, P.I. I'd like to ask you a few questions, if you don't mind.

Speaker: Finley
Dialogue: Finley T. Cod, customer. And yes, I do mind. Get lost, why don'tcha?

Speaker: Frog
Dialogue: Watch your tone. Where were you last night?

Speaker: Finley
Dialogue: I ain't gotta answer to some cop. Let me finish my drink in peace.

Speaker: Frog
Dialogue: I'll have you know I'm good cop. But I suggest you answer me, or I might have to haul in my associate. And you DON'T want to see him before his evening coffee. Gets cranky.

Speaker: Finley
Dialogue: Whatever. I was here, in the evening. Everyone can vouch for that.

Speaker: Frog
Dialogue: All night?

Speaker: Finley
Dialogue: Buzz off. I told you where I was.

Speaker: Frog
Dialogue: Alright, since you asked so nicely. But I've got my eye on you.

Speaker: Frog
Dialogue: You see anyone come in last night, around mid evening?

Speaker: Bartender
Dialogue: After you? No. But that fishy gentleman came in just before you. Wringing his hands under the table, looking around all scared, like. Asked for the strongest thing I had. None too kindly, either.

Speaker: Bartender
Dialogue: You think it was someone here?

Speaker: Frog
Dialogue: It would be an easy place to get to from the crime scene. But we won't know for sure unless we catch the bugger.

Speaker: Bartender
Dialogue: Good luck, Croaker. Bad energy afoot these days.

Speaker: NPC
Dialogue: Hey, funny story last night. I dropped by the Rum'n'Jazz for a buzz - Some TOTAL stranger comes up and says "Ay Sherry! Come over here and 'ave some drinks wiv us. LIVE a little."

Speaker: NPC2
Dialogue: What, like he knew you?

Speaker: NPC
Dialogue: Somethin like that. Everyone there's a bit heavy on the juice, if you catch my drift. Acted like he'd known me my whole life. Nice enough guy, but BOY, was he sozzled.

Speaker: Frog
Dialogue: Hmm….

Speaker: Lin
Dialogue: And THAT'S why I'm never experimenting with mayonnaise again.

Speaker: Ida
Dialogue: Blb. (Audible disgust)

Speaker: Scorpion
Dialogue: Anything useful?

Speaker: Frog
Dialogue: Some leads… and some things I could stand to never hear again.

Speaker: Scorpion
Dialogue: Oh?

Speaker: Frog
Dialogue: You don't want to know.

Speaker: Scorpion
Dialogue: I see…. Anyone acting strangely?

Speaker: Frog
Dialogue: A few. But run of the mill strange or lethally so?

Speaker: Frog
Dialogue: I'm not sure what to make of it. Nobody saw the killer. But there were some real oddballs in there. Some a little more aggressive than others… if that's anything to go by.

Speaker: Scorpion
Dialogue: So what now, then? We don't know where the killer went after he struck. Suspects, but no proof. Evidence, but we're missing the biggest one of all - the victim himself.

Speaker: Frog
Dialogue: Suppose we should head back to the office, then. We've not much to go on, and it's late. We'll work the rest out tomorrow.

Speaker: Scorpion
Dialogue: You're right. A good night's rest will do us both wonders.

Speaker: Lamp
Dialogue: A single, solitary streetlight. Many others like it, but this one is special. Its glow shines brighter than its peers, eclipsing its fellows with the power of its 80W SMD high-powered single colour semiconductor LED bulb. That's a lot of adjectives. It's quite proud of that.

Speaker: Lamp
Dialogue: So many feet have walked the cobbled stones that it spends every ounce of its wattage illuminating, but even our main characters cannot do much but stop and stare in awe at the splendour of this one, ordinary becoming extraordinary...

Speaker: Lamp
Dialogue: It's strange, but it almost seems like this ordinary streetlight looks…. proud of itself?

Speaker: Lamp
Dialogue: Stop conversing with the infrastructure. You have a case to solve.

Speaker: Lamp
Dialogue: I see you, player. Your hopes, your dreams. You cannot hide from the all-seeing eye of Lamp. What is it that you seek? Does ordinary life bore you, that you seek companionship in the mundane inventions of a people who no longer interest you?

Speaker: Lamp
Dialogue: One day, you'll look back on this conversation, and ask yourself…. What did I learn, from my incessant clicking? No, I'm not being rude. I'm tired. Go away.

Speaker: Scorpion
Dialogue: Blasted light. That one never works right.

Speaker: Scorpion
Dialogue: What's that?

Speaker: Frog
Dialogue: This looks like the receipts they have at the cafe.

Speaker: Scorpion
Dialogue: And the blood…. So our killer WAS there. And he headed in this direction. To the sewers I assume. We don't have time to waste.

Speaker: Frog
Dialogue: You're right. Whoever it was may even still be there. I should head back and see if I can apprehend them.

Speaker: Scorpion
Dialogue: Alone?

Speaker: Frog
Dialogue: They won't strike so openly again.

Speaker: Scorpion
Dialogue: Be safe, Ferd. I'll stay here and make sure we have all our evidence in one place.

Speaker: Scorpion
Dialogue: This is it. One last clue. One final piece of the puzzle.

Speaker: Scorpion
Dialogue: What was that? I could have sworn there was a clatter just now.

Speaker: Scorpion
Dialogue: I'd better investigate.

Speaker: Narrator
Dialogue: The light here is dim, and the smell of damp is pervasive. This place is unsettling.

Speaker: Scorpion
Dialogue: Was that a flash of red?

Speaker: Scorpion
Dialogue: Who's there?

Speaker: Narrator
Dialogue: There was no reply, save for the trickle of water running through the canal, and the steady drip-drip-drip of water falling from the ceiling.

Speaker: Scorpion
Dialogue: Hello?

Speaker: Narrator
Dialogue: Once again, silence. The track stops at a dead end, with only a dimly lit tunnel branching off to the side. Only one way to go - forward.

Speaker: Scorpion
Dialogue: Empty? But I could have sworn I saw someone… what's this?

Speaker: Scorpion
Dialogue: That's the sweet little girl I remember from the hospital all those years ago. A tragedy how she passed... but that person next to her I can't quite make them out. Why is this here?

Speaker: Frog
Dialogue: Look familiar?

Speaker: Narrator
Dialogue: Ernest spins around only to JUST barely dodge a hammer swing straight to the skull.

Speaker: Scorpion
Dialogue: What on earth are you doing?

Speaker: Frog
Dialogue: Oh, my sweet partner. Isn't it obvious?

Speaker: Narrator
Dialogue: Ferdinand swings again, but our hero, despite his poor vision, dances around.

Speaker: Scorpion
Dialogue: No. Do enlighten me.

Speaker: Frog
Dialogue: It's cold outside, you know.... The perfect temperature for a dish I've been preparing for a long, long time.

Speaker: Frog
Dialogue: Revenge.

Speaker: Narrator
Dialogue: Our valiant detective weaves, once again, but is spun off balance by a swing to his side.

Speaker: Frog
Dialogue: Why. Won't. You. DIE?

Speaker: Scorpion
Dialogue: What did I ever do to you, Ferd? What is this about?

Speaker: Narrator
Dialogue: Croaker's mouth twists into a bitter scowl as he advances, hammer raised.

Speaker: Frog
Dialogue: You don't even remember her, do you? The one who died so that you could live. You ROBBED her, and yet you live every day ungrateful for her sacrifice.

Speaker: Scorpion
Dialogue: Who?

Speaker: Frog
Dialogue: My sister.

Speaker: Scorpion
Dialogue: Ferd, I.. I didn't know.

Speaker: Frog
Dialogue: Don't play the fool with me. Your parents engineered her death, ensuring you got the heart that was meant for her. So I reaped their lives as payment for hers.

Speaker: Frog
Dialogue: With interest.

Speaker: Narrator
Dialogue: The hammer curves downward in a deadly arc, gleaming dull silver in the dim light. But this time, the P.I is faster. A hiss, a flash of barbed tail, and… it's over.

Speaker: Scorpion
Dialogue: I'm sorry, my friend. It didn't have to be like this.

Speaker: Frog
Dialogue: I have no regrets. The price for my sister was paid in blood.

Speaker: Scorpion
Dialogue: You're deranged.

Speaker: Frog
Dialogue: What of it?

Speaker: Scorpion
Dialogue: I hope you rot.

Speaker: Scorpion
Dialogue: It's been a month since I put my best friend behind bars. I suppose it's a relief to finally have closure… but the shock hasn't quite worn off. I'm packing up my practice, I've decided - I just don't think I can do this anymore.

Speaker: Scorpion
Dialogue: Besides I've solved my one big case. It's time… time to move on.
